turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: What the fuck is this guy doing?

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: This ain't no cop.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: It's a bunch of Jocks in a Granada!

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: They're fuckin' with us.

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: My brother's car!

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: All right. Die, Granada Jocks!

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: We just missed the turnoff to the party.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: You know the thing I love about Mustangs? The steering wheel.

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: My brother is going to kill us. He's gonna kill you and then he's gonna kill me. He's gonna kill us.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Just be glad you're all right.

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: My brother is gonna shit.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Make up your mind. Is he gonna shit, or is he gonna kill us?

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: First he's gonna shit. And then he's gonna kill us.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Will you just relax, mon? He's not gonna kill us. My father is a television repairman. He's got all kinds of tools. I can fix-this car.

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: You can't fix this car, Spicoli.

turns.speaker: L.C.
turns.text: That's him! He did it!

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Hey, mon, I don't know what your trip is, but...

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: How's it going.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Do you think that guy's cute?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Don't you like him?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Yeah, but I fucked up. You can take it. Really.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Come on, Stacy, it's your section and your man.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What should I do?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Just take his order, look him in the eye and if he says anything remotely funny, laugh a lot.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: He gave me his card.  'Ron Johnson, Audio Consultant.'

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Should we buy a frame for that?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Come on, Linda, I haven't had a boyfriend all summer. You promised when I started working at the mall that my life would change... Do you think he'll call this week?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Listen, Stace, you want to know about guys? I'll tell you. They're mostly chicken. Before I met Doug I chased after every guy I thought was cute. I thought if I gave out a vibe they'd get the message and call me up. Well, guess what? They don't call.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: So what did you do?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I called them. If I was sitting next to a guy and I wanted to sit closer, I'd sit closer. If I wanted to kiss him, I'd just do it. You want Ron Johnson? Grab him.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I can't do that.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Face it. With some guys you have to make the first move. A lot of guys are just... wussies.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Stacy, what are you waiting for? You're fifteen. I did it when I was thirteen. It's no huge thing. It's just sex. If you don't, one of the other girls will.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: He was hot, wasn't he?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: If I didn't have a fianc√© in Chicago, I'd go for it.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I can't believe I start high school tomorrow.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Believe it.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I hear some surfer pulled a knife on Mr. Hand this morning.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: No way! He just called him a dick.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: God. People exaggerate so much at this school.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Linda. That girl looks just like Pat Benatar.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Do you think guys find that attractive?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Oh, give me a break, Stacy. You're much prettier than them.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Yeah but they look more sophisticated. You'd probably think they'd be better in bed.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: What do you mean 'better in bed.' You either do it or you don't.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: No there are variables that, like, I might not be good at.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: What variables?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Like, you know, giving blow jobs.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: What's the big deal?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Well I never did it.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: There's nothing to it.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Just kidding. About 10cc.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Oh! That's where that group got its name from.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Was it great?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: It was okay.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You'll always remember your first time.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: It was nice.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: So tell me, do you like Ron? Is it serious?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Come on, Linda. It's just sex.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Hey! That's my line!

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: There... There's his car. I know he's at work tonight. He hasn't come into Swenson's since he called my house. My mother told him I was still at high school, after I told him I was nineteen. I guess I should tell him I'm fifteen.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Don't you dare, you'll never hear from him again.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Does Doug care that you're seventeen?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Doug sees beyond that stuff to what the person inside is like. That's why I'm marrying him.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: If he ever calls again I'll say I'm eighteen.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Boy I am so glad to be through with all these games.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You've got to get used to working Christmas. People are always screaming and yelling... then they get home and they're all Christmasy.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I think Christmas brings out the worst in people.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I guess Ron hasn't called yet.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Not since November.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Don't you think it meant anything to him. Even if I am fifteen?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Stacy. What does it matter? He's a stereo salesman. You want to marry him? You want to have kids with him? You want this guy to come home, fifty years old, and he's still got that little Pacific Stereo badge on? Come on.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I should quit this job. I'm going to get so fat working here... nobody will ever take me out.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Stacy. How many times do I have to tell you? You are really going to be beautiful... someday.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What do you think of that guy who works at the theatre? You know, Mark Ratner.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Oh, come on. What is he? Fifteen?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Sixteen.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I sent a letter to Doug today. I'll be so glad when he gets out here.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: You really ought to look at this, Linda. There's a drawing on every page... and all these quizzes. It's like school.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Why don't you put your mother's secret book back?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Listen to this... 'What are your mate's three most erogenous zones?'

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Okay, penis, that's one, balls...

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Wouldn't penis and balls be the same category?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You're right. Probably penis, mouth and neck.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: All right! Here's another one. 'The most satisfactory lovemaking occurs when your mate climaxes first, you climax first, you and your mate climax together?'

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Climax together.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Does that ever happen?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: No. But it's a nice idea.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Listen to this... it says 'Most women derive pleasure from sex, but they don't have real orgasms.'

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: How long does Doug take?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I don't know. Thirty to forty minutes.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What's Doug do in Chicago?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: He works for the airline. He'll be out here. You'll meet him.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I think they're both virgins.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I didn't ask for any help. Did you, Linda?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: God, he hardly even talks anymore.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I know. He hates to have to wear uniforms.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Stacy! I've got water in my ears. Do you have any Q-Tips?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: God, I don't think so. Better look in the house.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: God, Stacy, it's not that sad. It's just David Soul and Ricardo Montalban.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I don't know, I'm just so depressed. Everything is just so... depressing.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You have been acting very strange the last few weeks.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I don't know... I just don't feel right.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: What do you think it is?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What do you think it is?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: It couldn't be.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: It could be. I had a pregnancy test at the clinic. I'll find out Monday. I guess it was Damone.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Of course it was Damone. If it was Ron Johnson, you'd be out to here!

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I'm not going to tell him. He's an asshole. I hate him.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: But it costs money to have an abortion. Even at the Free Clinic. You tell Damone to pay for it. It's the least he can do. It's the guy's responsibility too.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: You know, there's one thing you didn't tell me about guys.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: You didn't tell me that they can be so nice, so great... but then you sleep with them and they start acting like they're five years old.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You're right. I didn't tell you that.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I really thought he would show up. I waited... and waited... and waited...

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: That little prick.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Then I called his house, and his mother told me he was in the garage helping his father.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: That little prick.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I paid for it and everything.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: There goes your stereo for another year. Mike Damone is a no-brain little prick. I'm not letting him get away with this.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Don't do anything, Linda. I'd rather just forget about it. I don't even like the guy.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Stacy, he's not a guy.  He's a little prick!

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Another summer of working at Swenson's.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Come on. There's lots of men around here. Keep your eyes open.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: You know, Linda. I've finally figured it out. It's not sex I want. Anyone can have sex.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I want romance.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Romance in Ridgemont? We don't even get cable TV.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Where's Doug?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: He's not coming.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Not coming? What happened?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: He says he's got to stay in Chicago.  He says I should visit him sometimes.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Sometime?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Yeah, like maybe never.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: But what are you going to do?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Well I might go to Dartmouth.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Dartmouth?!

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I didn't tell anyone I applied cause I never thought I'd make it.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I can't believe it! But what about Doug?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: There's a world of guys out there. I just wish I didn't have to date any of them.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Hey -- Doug Stallworth? It's his loss.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Yeah. I'm registered for this class.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: What class?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: This is U.S. History, right? I saw the globe in the window.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Can I come in?

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Oh, please. I get so lonely when that third attendance bell rings and I don't see all my kids here.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Mr. Spicoli?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: That's the name they gave me.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: You just ripped my card in two!

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Hey, bud. What's your problem?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Hey! Wait a minute! There's no birthday party for me here!

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Thank you, Desmond.  What's the reason for your truancy?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: I couldn't make it in time.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: You mean, you couldn't? Or you wouldn't?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: I don't know, mon. The food lines took forever.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Food will be eaten on your time!  Why are you continuously late for this class, Mr. Spicoli? Why do you shamelessly waste my time like this?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Am I hallucinating here? Just what in the hell do you think you're doing?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Learning about Cuba. Having some food.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Mr. Spicoli, you're on dangerous ground here. You're causing a major disturbance in my class and on my time.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: I've been thinking about this, Mr. Hand. If I'm here... and you're here... doesn't that make it our time?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: You better save some for me, you swine!

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: And you, my friend. I'll see you for a two-hour detention every afternoon this week.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Mr... Mr. Hand.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: That's right, Jeff. Mind if I come in?

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Were you going somewhere tonight, Jeff?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Yeah. The Graduation Dance Mr. Hand. It's the last school event of the year.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: I'm afraid we've got some things to discuss here, Jeff.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Did I do something wrong, Mr. Hand?

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Do you want to sit there, Jeff?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: I don't know. I guess so.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Fine. You sit right here on your bed. I'll use the chair here.  As I explained to your parents just a moment ago, and to you many times since the very beginning of the school year -- I don't like to spend my time waiting for late students, or detention cases. I'd rather be preparing the lesson.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Now, Mr. Spicoli, comes a rare moment for me. Now I have the unique pleasure of squaring our account. Tonight, you and I are going to talk in great detail about the Davis Agreement, all the associated treaties, and the American Revolution in particular. Now if you can just turn to Chapter 47 of Lord of Truth And Liberty.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Hey, it's in my locker, Mr. Hand.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Well, then, I'm glad I remembered to bring an extra copy just for you.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: I think I've made my point with you tonight.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Hey, Mr. Hand, can I ask you a question?

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Do you have a guy like me every year? A guy to... I don't know, make a show of. Teach other kids lessons and stuff?

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Well, you'll find out next year.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: No way, mon. When I graduate U.S. history I ain't even coming over to your side of the building.

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: If you graduate.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: You're gonna flunk me?!

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Don't worry, Spicoli. You'll probably squeak by.

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: All right! Oh, yeah!

turns.speaker: SPICOLI
turns.text: Aloha, Mr. Hand!

turns.speaker: MR. HAND
turns.text: Aloha, Spicoli.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: You look like you could still be in high school.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I know, everyone says that.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What can I get for you tonight.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: How about your phone number?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Thanks for picking me up.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: No problem.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: 'The Cuer-vo Gold, the fi-ine Columbian.'  You look nice tonight.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Thanks. So do you.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: Where do you feel like going?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I don't know. Wherever you want.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: How about the point?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: The point sounds fine.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: All right, the point it is.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: That's a nice shirt.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: Thanks. Thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: It's very warm out tonight.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: It is. It's very warm. I wonder how long it will last?

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: Are you really nineteen?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Yes... I am really nineteen.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: I think I better take you home.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What about those other guys you live with?

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: No. I mean back to your home.

turns.speaker: RON
turns.text: Is this your first time?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: What do you do with the jackets people leave here?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: We keep them.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: You keep them.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: We keep them, in case the people come back.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What's your other question?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: My other question is... can-I-have your-phone-number-so-I-can-ask-you out-sometime?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Do you have a pen? This one's out of ink.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Oh... yes.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Thanks for coming to get me.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Sure thing.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: This is a nice car.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Yeah. It's my sister's.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Do you have Mrs. George for English?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Yeah. She is pretty good.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Yeah. She is pretty good.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Joey at Cinema Four said this is a pretty good restaurant.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I've heard that, too.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Do you know what you want?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I think I'll have the Seafood Salad Special.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Excellent.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Oh yeah.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Do you mind if I excuse myself for a moment?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Sure. I'll... have another Coke.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Two more Cokes.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: I had a really nice time tonight.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Me, too. I'm real sorry someone broke in and stole your tape deck.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: I never thought it would happen at The Atlantis. Jeez.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Do you want to come inside?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Aren't your parents asleep?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: No, they're away for the weekend. Brad and I are watching the house.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Okay. Sure. I'll come in.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Where's your brother?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I don't know. Probably out. Want something to drink?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: No. That's okay.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Well, I'm going to change real quick. I hope you don't mind.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Naw. I don't mind.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: So... pretty nice house you've got here.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Thanks. So...  What do you want to do?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Do you want to see some pictures? I kept a lot of scrapbooks and pictures and stuff from junior high. How stupid, right?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: This is me in the eighth grade. Did you have Mr. Deegan?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Oh, yeah. I had Mr. Deegan.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: ...I've got to go home.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Do you really have to go?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Well... it's getting kind of late.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Where's Mike today?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Today's April 16th. Damone never comes to school on April 16th.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What's April 16th?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: It's John Bonham's birthday.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: John Bonham?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: John Bonham. The drummer for Led Zeppelin. He died a couple years ago. Every birthday he stays home and plays everything John Bonham ever recorded. It's like his own holiday.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Oh. I see.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I made a fool of myself.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Nobody noticed. Don't worry about it. We'll just stay out here until everyone comes out, we'll blend back in.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: What about the notes?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: I'll get you the notes.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Hi, Mark.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Hi, Stacy. How are you?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I'm fine. Mark, I'm so glad you came over here because I want you to know something. I just thought I would tell you that I really enjoyed getting to know you this year.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Yeah? About fifty people I didn't know wrote that in my annual.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I know everybody says it, but I really mean it.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Yeah. I want you to have this picture, so you won't forget what I look like. And so you'll remember to call me over the summer.

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Well, I don't know, I may be doing some traveling this summer. I don't know how much I'll be around...  But I'll give you a call sometime.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I'd like that.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Are you ready to order here?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Well... sure.  She will have the Seafood Salad Special. And I will have... the same.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Anything to drink?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: Two Cokes.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Okay. Thanks.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Are you sure there's nothing else I can bring you?

turns.speaker: THE RAT
turns.text: I'll have one more Coke... Do you want another Coke, Stacy?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Sir?  This telegram came for you. Actually, it isn't for you. It's for somebody named Thompson, but it says 'care of Raoul Duke'. Does that make sense?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Yes... It makes sense.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: I checked the register for this man Thompson. We don't show him but I figured he might be part of your team.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: He is. Don't worry, I'll get it to him.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: What confused us was Dr. Gonzo's signature on the telegram from Los Angeles. When we knew he was right here in the hotel.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: You did the right thing. Never try to understand a press message. About half the time we use codes -- especially with Dr. Gonzo.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Tell me. When will the doctor be awake?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Awake? What do you mean?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Well... the manager, Mr. Heem, would like to meet him. Nothing unusual. Mr. Heem likes to meet all our large accounts... put them on a personal basis... just a chat and a handshake, you understand.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Of course. But if I were you, I'd leave the Doctor alone until after he's eaten breakfast. He's a very crude man.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: But he will be available? Perhaps later this morning?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Look. That telegram was all scrambled. It was actually from Thompson, not to him. Western Union must have gotten the names reversed. I have to get going. I have to get out to the track.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: There's no hurry! The race is over!

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Not for me.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Let's have lunch!

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Righto!

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Of course, I could hear what the Clerk was really saying...

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Listen, you fuzzy little shithead -- I've been fucked around, in my time, by a fairly good cross-section of mean-tempered rule-crazy cops and now it's MY turn. "Fuck you, officer, I'm in charge here, and I'm telling you we don't have room for you."

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Certainly, Mr. Duke!

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: My bags are out there in that white Cadillac convertible. Can you have someone drive it around to the room?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Oh, and could I get a quart of Wild Turkey, two fifths of Baccardi, and a night's worth of ice delivered to my room, please?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Don't worry about a thing, sir. Just enjoy your stay.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Well, thank you.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: What's the message? My light is blinking.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Ah, yes. Mr. Duke? You have one message: "Call Lucy at the Americana Hotel, room 1600."

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Holy shit!

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Mr. Duke? Hello, Mr. Duke, I'm sorry we were cut off a moment ago... I thought I should call again, because I was wondering...

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: WHAT?  What was that crazy bitch said to him?  There's a war on, man! People are being killed!

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Killed?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: IN VIETNAM! ON THE GODDAMN TELEVISION!

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Oh... yes... yes... This terrible war. When will it end?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Tell me. What do you want?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: The woman who left that message for you sounded very disturbed. I think she was crying...

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Crying? Why was she crying?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Well, uh. She didn't say Mr. Duke. But since I know you're here with the Police Convention...

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Look, you want to be gentle with that woman if she ever calls again. We're watching her very carefully... this woman has been into laudanum. It's a controlled experiment, but I suspect we'll need your cooperation before this thing is over.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Well, certainly... We're always happy to cooperate with the police...

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Don't worry. You're protected. Just treat this poor woman like you'd treat any other human being in trouble.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: What? Ah... yes, yes, I see what you mean... Yes... so, you'll be responsible then?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Of course. And now I have to get back to the news. Send up some ice.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Rum and ice, please.

turns.speaker: DA
turns.text: You're another one of these California boys. Your friend here's been tellin' us about dope fiends.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: They're everywhere. Nobody's safe. And sure as hell not in the South. They like warm weather... You'd never believe it. In L.A. it's out of control. First it was drugs, now it's witchcraft.

turns.speaker: DA
turns.text: Witchcraft? Shit, you can't mean it!

turns.speaker: DA
turns.text: Naw! That's science fiction stuff!

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Not where we operate.

turns.speaker: DA
turns.text: Naked!?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Naked.
